snippet.title: Ivy, Piano Room rape charges expected to be dropped
snippet.content:
Ivy, Piano Room rape charges expected to be dropped
Chris Corben, covering his face and head, runs from Surry Hills Police Station in an attempt to flee the waiting media in 2009.
exit
ONE of two rape charges against a man accused of sexually assaulting two women in separate attacks at exclusive Sydney nightclubs is expected to be dropped, police and legal sources have told The Sun-Herald. It is also understood the defence team for accused Bondi accountant Christopher Scott Corben, 31, will apply to have the second charge dropped when the case comes before Downing Centre Local Court tomorrow. Mr Corben's solicitor, Nick Boyden, was not available for comment but it is understood he has briefed Winston Terracini, SC, to make the application for the Director of Public Prosecutions to dismiss a charge against his client of having allegedly raped a well-known fashion designer in a change room cubicle at the exclusive Ivy bar in October 2009. The application will be made at the same time as the DPP is expected to formally withdraw a charge against Mr Corben of having raped another woman in an unconnected attack in the Piano Room, Kings Cross, a year earlier. The alleged victim in the Ivy case told prosecutors early last month that she would not be available to give evidence at tomorrow's hearing because of her commitments at Australian Fashion week in Sydney. The DPP had sought unsuccessfully to vacate the hearing because it clashed with fashion week. Late last year magistrate Caleb Franklin found ''a number of inconsistencies'' in the two complainants' versions, saying ''special reasons'' gave rise to an order that both alleged victims be required for cross-examination ''in the interests of justice''. Mr Corben is on strict bail conditions. He must live at his parents' Lilli Pilli home, abide by a strict curfew, and not drink alcohol or visit licensed premises. In October 2009, Mr Corben was charged with aggravated sexual assault and deprivation of liberty of a woman, 34, in a toilet at the Ivy nightclub in George Street, Sydney. Two months later he was charged with sexual intercourse without consent, taking and detaining a person with the intention to obtain advantage and two counts of assault with an act of indecency against a woman, 25, in a toilet at the Piano Room bar in Kings Cross in October 2008.
